Topic.Title: Gelsinger (currently EMC ceo) says he is skeptical of ARM based servers....

Message.Msg: anandtechDOTcom/print/6757/calxedas-arm-server-tested Basically a 24 ARM socket server (96 A9 cores) was in the same ballpark for webhosting (but nothing else) as a 2 socket x86 server (16 Xeon cores), Considering the Romley E5 octo-core is a part primarily designed for 4 socket systems, this Boston server would lose on performance, performance/watt and price to such a 4-way Romley system. A15 and A57 do not have better performance/power than A9 which is quite a power efficient part (see Tegra 4i) so ARM is going to fail at general purpose servers. The only hope for these ARM servers is in HPC/render farms where say the potent floating point power of A15 might give it some competitive edge in say performance/watt/price although again that still has to be proven. After this review was released ARMH dropped 3% as anybody not biased can see all the ARM claims of great performance/watt superiority over x86 are overblown/non-existent like I stated earlier with previous examples.

Message.Title: Apple's next-gen A7 processor reportedly being ready for TSMC production by 20nm process
Message.Msg: SOURCE: Appleinsider ""A report from the Far East cites sources who expect Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company to "tape out" Apple's A7 SoC this month ahead of risk production in early summer, suggesting that future iOS devices may not rely solely on silicon manufactured by Samsung. According to DigiTimes, industry sources say that TSMC is ready to "tape out" the new A7 chip on its 20nm process, with the processors scheduled to be implanted into Apple products in the first quarter of 2014. While the publication has a questionable track record, Thursday's report echoes recent accounts that said TSMC has started production of certain Apple chips as part of a long-rumored partnership. As noted by CNET, TSMC is expected to reach the "tape out" stage — which references the photomasking process that is one of the final steps in circuit design — for the A7 in March and move into early production in either May or June. The firm will reportedly expand operations at its "14-fab" located in Tainan Science Park, with investments in production facilities said to reach nearly $17 billion. TSMC set a capital expenditure budget of $9 billion for 2013, an increase of $700 million from 2012. The report claims that about 90 percent of this year's capex will be put toward bolstering output of chips based on company's 28nm process. The Taiwanese firm said in January that it forecasts a near 100 percent ownership of the 28nm chip market during 2013, a statement that sparked speculation of massive orders from Apple."" PS: Read and believe at your own discretion.

I would think you refer to me when you say Frank. However I am not discouraged a bit and have no intention to give up or the like and I believe my posts support this stance. I am probably old school character with patience built in. First and foremost I subscribe to many of Peter Lynch's values for investments. I focus on the company first (fundamentals) and the pps a distant second. Of course I judge pps against fundamentals and potential growth and I like what I find regarding Nvidia. Being able to use and evaluate their products makes the investment within my circle of competence. I am excited to see what Nvidia does in the next two years and I am confident the pps will be much higher then. Take care all /Frank.

Message.Title: Trefis: a closer look at how NVIDIA lifts its outlook
Message.Msg: Quick take: --Despite the PC slowdown, Nvidia posted record revenues and margins in its fiscal 2013 and Tegra revenues grew from $198 million in 2010 to $765 million in 2012 --Combined smartphone and tablet sales are estimated to grow at a CAGR of 19% through 2016 and we forecast Tegra sales to grow at a CAGR of 17% --Nvidia introduced its next generation Tegra 4 processor and the Tegra 4i, which features built in 3G and 4G/LTE communication technologies leading to major design wins --4G/LTE is the future of wireless connectivity for mobile devices and LTE is seeing the strongest growth among the various technologies that are driving the mobile market trefisDOTcom/stock/nvda/articles/172863/a-closer-look-at-how-tegra-is-helping-lift-nvidias-outlook/2013-03-14

Message.Title: NVDA versus NVDA
Message.Msg: It is reasonably valid to believe that NVDA as a company is a good company, with a solid future and an excellent balance sheet. But it is also valid to believe that the company's stock has become a perennial underperformer. I liken it to INTC, which has fundamentally similar positive characteristics (and even a great dividend yield for a tech company) and whose stock has done nothing for years. I can't explain why, but the market simply doesn't care for these stocks.

Message.Title: Why isn't Moving up with HP announcement?
Message.Msg: Should be flying today...no? HP is re-entering an NVIDIA-powered (NVDA) tablet, by using the Tegra 4 chip. The move bodes well for both companies. There have not been as many Tegra 4 adoptions announced as investors would like. For HP, the adoption of Android for tablets is an extension of its computer diversification. The inexpensive Google (GOOG) Chromebook is made by HP.

That has been the great mystery as a whole. But again, you will find quite a few stocks of really good companies doing nothing. And the fact that the market is putting a historically powerful rally this really bodes very bad for stocks such as NVDA.

I've always thought of you as a tech expert, with real-life experience, so I was worried when the person I thought was you said they were giving up. I've just gotten back from running around all morning, and as I've tried to say, the ONLY time of the day that REALLY matters is the FINAL HOUR. The rest is NOISE. So, volume IS higher than this time, yesterday, and there have been a LOT of blocks, and the attempt to take the stock down and hold it there isn't working, so far. Perhaps, we'll get the OPPOSITE of yesterday, and finish at the highs of the day. For that to happen we'll likely need to see volume back over 12-15mm shares. The game is NOT over for this week until 4PM, Friday. As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. Best, Max

Topic.Title: Why isn't Moving up with HP announcement?

Message.Msg: Wall Street always has double standards. For established and "in vogue" companies like Google or Qualcomm, the mere paper announcement of a new technology would be sufficient to cause a spike in stock price. However, for innovative companies like NVIDIA opening new territories with uncertainties, WS demands to see the top and bottom number for at least several quarters before lending its sustained support. Cramer effect or other upgrades by 2nd tier brokerages don't really count. One of my brokers once told me that while the tech stalwarts can be treated well when their performance is good, smaller innovative companies like nVIdia has to be GREAT in order to get a favorable treatment by the Street. That is just how it works - WS values "certainty" above a lot of other redeeming values. That said, I am confident NVDA will get there in a year or two, or perhaps sooner. GOOG and QC didn't achieve their current status overnight; both stocks went through their respective treacherous routes before just like nVIDIA has been. I know because I owned both GOOG and QCOM although I sold QC many years ago. PS: Frank is also my guiding light on this board. if (God forbid) he ever declares that he might be leaving this stock, I would seriously consider doing the same. Other posters serve as a contrarian indicator to me - no names to be mentioned here - despite their professed "long" standing. I would be more comfortable if they did not hold NVDA shares.

Message.Title: Not Sure Nvidia's Marketing Is Correct In Their Posturing On the PS4, MS Consols
Message.Msg: I understand where they are coming from...spinning the loss of the game consols to AMD. They are correct in that it is lower margin and perhaps correct that they didn't have enough engineers and there was an opportunity cost involved. But in reality when the game console industry decided to build consoles with essentially X86 off the shelf parts, Nvidia simply did not have anything to compete with. AMD did. If this was 2014 or certainly 2015 then a Tegra chipset running Android or some proprietary software might have been a consideration. I do believe that open Android platform gaming is here and will grow, but traditional game consoles will continue to sell. Surprised AMD's PPS has not benefited from it. Perhaps their financial situation is more dire than is let on. I do expect to hear March 19th where all that opportunity cost engineering went and what the favorable financial impact going forward in 2013 will be. Specifics will be appreciated.

Topic.Title: Not Sure Nvidia's Marketing Is Correct In Their Posturing On the PS4, MS Consols

Message.Msg: Nvidia never supplied the CPU portion for any game console, so for Nvidia to claim they turned down the PS4 business is nonsense. Sony would still need a 64 bit CPU with any Nvidia GPU part. And as has been reported Nvidia did try to market Tegra 4 as a game console part as was rejected. Nvidia does not have a 64 bit part to sell, a 32 bit Tegra 4 can't compete with the current PS3 which has a 64 bit CPU and Nvidia GPU so who is Nvidia kidding. Sure it would cost a fortune to develope a 64 bit CPU+GPU chip for a PS4 product if you don't have a 64 bit CPU to start with. Sour grapes is all Nvidia has to fall back on now and a SHIELD toy. imho

Message.Title: HP re-entering the Android mobile market with Tegra 4 tablet
Message.Msg: A chronically weak 2012 for the PC market made it more difficult for HP to recover. HP is relying on server hardware and corporate software sales to make up for the lost revenue. Growth in mobile devices like tablets were out of the picture, until now, thanks to tablets. HP is re-entering an NVIDIA-powered (NVDA) tablet, by using the Tegra 4 chip. The move bodes well for both companies. There have not been as many Tegra 4 adoptions announced as investors would like. For HP, the adoption of Android for tablets is an extension of its computer diversification. The inexpensive Google (GOOG) Chromebook is made by HP. 3 Winners: NVIDIA, HP, GOOG 1 Loser: MSFT thestreetDOTcom/story/11869920/1/3-winners-and-a-loser-as-hp-adopts-android.html

Topic.Title: Not Sure Nvidia's Marketing Is Correct In Their Posturing On the PS4, MS Consols

Message.Msg: I believe the engineers is a very important part of the decision process. But take Projekt Shield and take Ouya and probably Wikipad. Those handheld game consoles will fully support the Android eco system and available games. Gamers can have games for free or for a very small amount of money. All purchased Android games are available on the new device and the Shield will soon support Grid gaming and can even stream games from the PC. Together with smartphones and Android Tablets they will reinforce the Android Eco system and still more Game developers will be drawn to Android and eventually the feature set and game complexity will grow. But perhabs an even more important point is the life-span of each model. There will be a new Shield model each year and now also a new Ouya model each year. Gamers only have to use 100 dollars for the Ouya and instantly have a backlog of games and next year they can buy a second game console with upgraded hardware and backwards compability, but perhabs with new enabled features ingame. I think this low threshold barrier will make the new consoles from Sony and Microsoft obsolete much faster if they still intend to maintain at least a five year life-span. As supplement info - read: engadgetDOTcom/2013/02/13/ouya-nvidia-lovefest/ P.S. Thanks for your compliment earlier on. I try to be honest with how i see things but you can probably colour me a fan-boy of Nvidia - so be careful :-D

Topic.Title: Not Sure Nvidia's Marketing Is Correct In Their Posturing On the PS4, MS Consols

Message.Msg: The Biz Model for all the old consoles - XBox, PS4, Wii are based on giving away the console and making a tonne on the games. They have to subsidize the boxes out of their own pockets - unlike smartphones where a 2nd party the carrier do the subsidizing. So MS, Sony and Nintendo would be very aggressive with the purchase price of the components - it's a race to the bottom and AMD got it - knowing how desperate they were - they were probably still dropping their pants after Nvidia left the room :)

Message.Title: Who is Nvidia kidding, they don't have a 64 bit CPU to sell Sony or anyone else
Message.Msg: How can Nvidia claim to have turned down the PS4 business when the current PS3 runs on a someone elses 64 bit CPU and Nvidia GPU. Nvidia does not have a 64 bit CPU to sell so Sony would still need to save some big bucks for the CPU if it went with an Nvidia GPU. Forget Tegra 4, why would Sony want to produce a PS4 with less horsepower then the current PS3? Tegra 4 is all Nvidia has and a 32 bit Tegra 4 can't compete with the current 64 bit PS3. Nvidia has nothing to offer Sony without an AMD, Intel or IBM supplybg a real 64 bit CPU so Nvidia was NEVER going to get what a single source CPU+GPU supplier would. For Nvidia the PS4 was a chance to supply a GPU for AMD its a chance to supply the CPU plus GPU and rake in the CPU plus GPU money. imho
Thank you !

Message.Title: NVIDIA "didn't want" the Playstation 4
Message.Msg: by Cyril Kowaliski — 3:05 PM on March 14, 2013 AMD has scored a big design win with the PlayStation 4. When the console comes out later this year, it will pack an AMD-designed APU with eight x86 processor cores and Radeon-derived graphics. That will be a stark departure from the Cell-and-GeForce combo of the PlayStation 3. So, why didn't Nvidia get the win this time? GameSpot broached the subject with Tony Tamasi, Nvidia's Senior VP of Content and Technology, who provided an interesting answer. By the sound of it, Nvidia may have turned down Sony and not the other way around. "We came to the conclusion that we didn't want to do the business at the price those guys were willing to pay," Tamasi told GameSpot. "We had to look at console business as an opportunity cost," he added. "If we . . . did a console, what other piece of our business would we put on hold to chase after that?" In the end, Nvidia apparently chose to prioritize its internal projects over a venture with Sony. Tamasi concludes, "We'll see how that plays out from a business perspective . . . It's clearly not a technology thing." Perhaps he's right, but there may be more of a technology gap than he lets on. AMD was able to give Sony some relatively powerful x86 CPU cores and a state-of-the-art GPU on a single chip, using proven technology. Nvidia, on the other hand, lacks an x86 license and still hasn't announced products based on Project Denver, its upcoming, ARMv8-powered 64-bit processor. Perhaps the firm could have cobbled together a chip with Tegra 4 processor cores and Kepler GPU logic, but the AMD solution does seem more befitting of a next-gen console, at least to my eyes. SOURCE: techreportDOTcom/news/24501/nvidia-didnt-want-the-playstation-4 ________ PS: Exactly as Norcal, Frank and I posted....a straight forward decision and a right one.
Good find :-D

General comments from Tamasi are consistent with other articles, but I think the writer has it a little mixed up in his assumptions about what Nvidia has right now available for Playstation and any other console . . it's a weird commentary that is off-track. Don't think the writer understands how the Shield console does everything the Playstation will do and more . .

"PS: Exactly as Norcal, Frank and I posted....a straight forward decision and a right one." OK.....Now Let's see the financials on What they Do Want To do? Thankfully Jensen is scheduled to do just that Tuesday March 19th.

The most important point of the article is the Tony Tomasi quote. If the quote is correct, that will serve to support the title. The "tune" of the author or how much he knows is less important. You seem to go off the focus a bit.
Good report ;)

Message.Title: Win 9 tablets threaten the IPAD dominance in enterprise, says Patrick Moorhead
Message.Msg: SOURCE: ZDNet zdnetDOTcom/new-windows-powered-tablets-threaten-ipads-enterprise-dominance-claims-analyst-7000012624/ One more "sin" added to the long list of such held by AAPL. :)

I beg to differ, the author gives more time to his speculation on what Nvidia could have done without noting how the Shield is put together (and that has been out for a while in press releases) in contrast to his assumption about what Nvidia can and cannot do. So no, the 'tune' matters a great deal because it is what the author leaves people thinking at the end of the article, which really doesn't support the actual quote but in fact questions what Nvidia could have done, at least indirectly.

Roundhouse_c, I own shares in Nvidia like you do, but I do see how the Tech Press and many commentators on Gaming boards are starting to view The Shield and this is a failure of marketing rather than technology. Today I saw an article labeled: "Nvidia continues with their C**k tease of The Shield." The time frame from announcement 1/6/13 to today 3/14 is 2.5 months with no pricing, no pre-order date, and ship date. This is really starting to turn off potential buyers. Specifics are needed now if Nvidia expects to maintain any goodwill into launch. I also saw two other older articles suggesting that Nvidia launched The Shield because they couldn't get into the Playstation 4. If this continues for a few more weeks Nvidia's marketing may never recover. For factual data look at the view numbers on the Project Shield twice weekly videos on youtube. They are 1/5 of what the first few weeks were. A Classic Marketing Error!

Topic.Title: Win 9 tablets threaten the IPAD dominance in enterprise, says Patrick Moorhead

Message.Msg: Think you meant 'Win 8' but point taken . .

Topic.Title: Win 9 tablets threaten the IPAD dominance in enterprise, says Patrick Moorhead

Message.Msg: Yes, thanks for the correction of typo. (Got fat fingers!)
Thanks !
You Watch to get a grip of The device, not to See All potential games. Once accomplished you can skip videos. IMHO

Message.Title: Digitimes is confirming what Jensen said. TSMC 20nm is Baloney and is
Message.Msg: delayed until mid 2014, with Volume production in 2015. GAME OVER!!!

Topic.Title: Digitimes is confirming what Jensen said. TSMC 20nm is Baloney and is

Message.Msg: irrelevant

makes sense Frank. At least they only did one video this week. Smart move. Since GTC is almost all about gaming, Nvidia Grid, Project Shield, and Android game Developers, I think it would be a good place and time for Jensen to announce the price and start taking pre orders. What is curious is Digitimes is silent on who is producing the device. Makes me think they may doing the manufacture in a San Jose Contract manufacturer where they built the prototypes. Production should have already started, at least by the end of March to launch in Q2. Here's hoping Nvidia marketing doesn't do a big hoopla on it and then no product launch for 3 months. Note: The price is the price. Sony and Microsoft won't give prices until much later. JMHO
Sorry, but that sounds like "sour grapes"

Message.Title: Good News, If Nvidia didn't want PS4 MONEY they won't see a PS4 dime, Sony chose AMD.
Message.Msg: Nvidia does not get to decide what part Sony uses in the PS4, Sony has that job. All Nvidia can do now is sit back and SUCK on sour grapes and spew BS all day about not wanting to make money in consoles. Nvifdia does not have a 64 bit CPU which the current PS3 and the PS4 REQUIRED so Nvidia had nothing to sell anyway. With no 64 bit CPU all Nvidia can do is whne about getting fired from their PlayStation job. The PlayStation 4 Job is AMDs now and the PlayStation PAY CHECK. Sony went with a single source for CPU and GPU. imho

Topic.Title: Who is Nvidia kidding, they don't have a 64 bit CPU to sell Sony or anyone else

Message.Msg: Nvidia didn't have what Sony wanted. How could Nvidia supply Sony with a 64 bit CPU when Nbidia doesn't have a 64 bit CPU? lol Since current the PS3 is 64 bit why would Sony waste time evaluating a weak 32 bit Tegra 4? Intel didn't have the GPU muscle and Nvidia didn't have the CPU muscle. Now say it ain't so. imho

Message.Title: 4 Big Tablets Launches To Watch For In May And June
Message.Msg: 1) Kindle Fire 7 inch replacement 2) Google Nexus 7 replacement 3) Google Nexus 10 replacement 4) Surface RT replacement All announcements should come within weeks of each other. Will Nvidia be 4 for 4, 0 for 4, or somewhere in between with Tegra 4. We should be able to read the slides and the body language when Jensen presents Nvidia's Financial Presentation Tuesday March 19th at GTC. Strange but no leaks reported by Digitimes other than a May launch for a new Kindle Fire. No specifics.

Topic.Title: Not Sure Nvidia's Marketing Is Correct In Their Posturing On the PS4, MS Consols

Message.Msg: "why Nvidia just doesn't say that" asked and answered. In 2009. Analysts pushed this issue then. NVDA's answer was they saw no future in x86. NVDA certainly didn't want to play Intel's game by Intel's rules, it's very clear how far that got AMD. The last few years confirmed NVDA's forecast. Jensen called it right. I'd certainly give up a few 10s of million units of low margin opportunity for a billion plus high margin one, as I say, no brainer.

Topic.Title: Not Sure Nvidia's Marketing Is Correct In Their Posturing On the PS4, MS Consols

Message.Msg: True, but then you have some marketing guy spinning like they could make an X86 CPU which the entire world knows they can't. This is where Nvidia's credibility issue comes from. The Spin of Their Marketing Guys! When spinning it's important to include the truth. A more appropriate quote would have been: "When Sony decided to go with a PC type CPU/GPU X86 we dropped out because as you know we do not have am X86 license. Besides the margins were low and we had plenty of opportunities elsewhere." Hopefully we will see the effect of those other opportunities during Jensen's March 19th financial presentation.
